questions.output: Who is the caller? (Full Name, DOB, Address, Phone #)
Is break and enter in progress or not? (If in progress, advise other units)
In the event of an 'in progress' break and enter, acquire details of the property (entrances and exits)
Is anyone home?
Any weapons on premises?
Caller's relationship to property broken into.
Who owns the property?
Who noticed the B&E?
Did anyone enter? If yes, who and what path did they take?
Did anyone touch anything? If so, what?
Who will be on the scene when police/investigator arrive?
Did they notice anyone suspicious in the area?
Any suspects, witnesses or physical evidence?
Tell caller not to let anyone near the scene until police arrive.
If B&E in progress, consider canine unit. (Fresh scent of perpetrator on scene)
Is Anybody fleeing scene while en-route? (On foot, in vehicle, etc.)
Do not drive over scene, park at a distance so not to disturb or contaminate any evidence or foot/tire prints.
Confirm B&E with whomever reported it.
Secure scene(s).
Take names of everyone on scene. (Full Name, DOB, Address, Phone #)
Take initial picture of the scene when you arrive. (Try to capture everyone on site in your photo)
Separate witnesses and/or victim(s).
Determine timeline. When last person attended the property prior to B&E? Also first person to arrive after B&E.
Commence a scene log to track who comes and goes. (Take names of everyone on scene)
Find out who victim/owner of property is.
Document the crime scene as you found it.
One entrance One exit.
What path did perpetrator take? (Include both inside premises and outside premises and perimeter)
Ask when floors were cleaned.
Skirt wall, walk along wall, suspect(s) will take path of least resistance.
Confirm if scene was disturbed. Who, when and where did they go?

Search perimeter for evidence. Footprints in mud, dirt, snow, flower beds (glass is where best footprints are found), tire impressions. Also look for tools used to break in, suspects clothing/disguises, cigarette butts, footprints/shoe impressions etc. Check inside and perimeter area for footprints.
Determine if 'Forensic Identification Section' required.
questions.note: If yes to one or more of the items below, contact 'Forensic Identification Section'.

questions.output: Do fingerprints need to be lifted from secured objects?
Do Shoe or foot impressions need to be lifted from secured objects?
What is the severity of B&E? (value, victims on scene during) Has there been a rash of breaks lately, etc.?
Is there a need for more professional photographs?
What is the likelihood of fingerprints/footprints/shoe impressions being lifted? (Dusty surfaces, smeared prints, gloves being used, etc.)
Are there tire impressions?
Was DNA left behind. Broken glass, cigarette butts, urine, feces, saliva, etc.?
Are other special units are required/available. B&E section, 'General Investigation Section', etc.?
Determine force used to enter property
When was scene found broken into? (Date and time)
What was the point of entry?
Method of entry?
What was stolen? make, model, serial #s, description, color, value, number of items taken. ( are there receipts).
Describe items without serial numbers with great detail, include defects and other identifiers. (Include in statement)
Try to obtain photos of stolen items from victim.
Where were stolen items located prior to removal?
Was anything disturbed or touched?

Are there signs of any unusual suspect behavior? Drinking alcohol, smoking, burning matches, defecation, handling of female undergarments, made themselves at home, urination, used gloves, mask, used the telephone, tissue/towels, weapons, graffiti, vandalism. Any other points of contact made by suspect? (Some suspects have been known to use the bathroom, eat and/or drink on scene)
Photograph and describe any evidence that you cannot take.
Can physical evidence be seized? (Items possibly handled or disturbed i.e. Papers, removable drawers, screens, tools, etc.)
Take samples of material left behind that might match the evidence on a suspect. (clothing, hair, blood, glass, drywall dust, etc)
What was the point of exit?
Photograph scene. including POE's, pathway, where stolen items taken from, any damages, any type of impressions. (tire, foot, fingerprints)
Is there surveillance video available?
If there was an alarm, was it activated or disabled? When? (was the phone line cut?)

Survey Neighbourhood, make inquiries to find out if anyone suspicious in area prior to break or in the past. Did they notice any lights on, any noise, what time they went to bed and woke up, likelihood of hearing or seeing break.
Take detailed notes.
Victim(s)

additionalQuestions.output: If at any point during the victim statement if the victim becomes a suspect in the offence, read victim his rights and attempt a cautioned statement.
Who would know where valuables are in the building? (i.e. Possible suspect would know location of safe and hiding spots)
Determine timeline, when property was last seen prior to break, when break was noticed, by whom?
Was property secured? How?
Identify the condition of the property prior to B&E. Floors and counters just cleaned, preparing for seasonal use, etc.
Did anyone make any changes to the scene before the police arrived?
What was damaged?
What was stolen? Make, model, description, current or original value ($), serial numbers.
What is at the scene that normally wouldn't be there?
Does anyone else have access to property? Possible suspects, witnesses for elimination prints, past or present employees/key-holders, etc.
Do they suspect anyone?
Any prior issues with any individual(s)? Friends, family, acquaintances, employees past or present, neighbors, etc.
Unusual loiterers, visitors, parked cars, or phone calls before the break and enter?
Who would have had the opportunity to act?
Any previous B&E's at the property or other properties owned by the victim(s)?
Possibility of inside job?
If it is a business, name of employees. (Full Name, DOB, Address, Phone #)
Would employees be willing to fill out view questionnaire or agree to polygraph?
Insurance company and if there will be a claim?
Does the victim have an alibi and who can confirm?
Do you need to move into an interrogation? If so, take a video recorded statement. Bring accused back to station.
Would the victim be willing to take a polygraph? Have victim sign a form ' Polygraph Consent Form '. (Used later to setup an appointment. Only on suspicion)
Advise the victim of 'Victim Impact Statement'.

questions.output: Witness

additionalQuestions.output: Full Name, DOB, Address, Phone #.
Relationship to property/victim.
Determine timeline. (who was last to attend property and first to find property broken into)
What did they witness? (Suspect(s), other witnesses, scene, stolen items, etc.)
If they have suspect(s), provide detail description(s) of suspect(s) and clothing. Where they saw suspect(s), how suspect(s) fled the scene, etc.
Whom they suspect as being involved and why?
Any knowledge of what was stolen? (description, value, serial numbers, etc)
Is information provided reliable? (how and why)
Any other pertinent information that can be provided will vary from witness to witness.

questions.output: Determine Modus Operandi. Is this crime similar to others in the area?
Check prior B&E's for suspects and suspect vehicles.
Add all stolen items and serial numbers to CPIC. (NCIC in US)
Contact owner/victim/witnesses to see if they have any new avenues to follow up with.
Contact pawn shops to see if stolen items have been pawned.
If items are located in pawn shops. (Seize items, obtain video of suspect pawning items, when was item pawned, obtain statement from pawn shop employee.)
Canvass sources for information.
Media release, social media and crime stoppers.
Email to other members not working and other detachments or police forces, as well as other intelligence sections working on similar files.
Complete required documents. Occurrence reports, exhibit reports, forensic identification requests, enter all data, photos, statements, notes, receipts, referral forms, CPIC printouts added to file.
Contact criminal intelligence section to see if rash of B&E's or if there are suspects in other files that meet MO.
Keep eye out for other possible related B&E or suspects.
Have other members question any detained clients with regards to this crime.
Determine if stolen electronics can be tracked via GPS (Smart phones, laptops, tablets, etc).
Update Forensic Identification Section on the investigation. (suspect(s) names)
Elimination Prints as soon as possible.
Tools and metal components can be compared.
Have any physical evidence analyzed. Ensure forensics adds details to file.

Have Emergency Medical Services attend!

questions.output: Conduct NOK's if needed
If autopsy to be conducted secure body and submit required documentation and forward required messages
If no autopsy to be conducted write up file and conclude
If death took place at a workplace, contact workplace health and safety
All scene's must be assessed for potentially bio hazardous material. Including the presence of a dangerous suspect
Do not enter a scene that you suspect has been exposed to chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear (CBRN) agents
If cause of death was electrical, stay back and ensure local power company cuts power prior to approaching scene
Protect yourself and the public from further danger or exposure
Secure the scene and request assistance
If there is no indication of CBRN contamination or electrical hazards secure the scene for investigation
Do not allow unauthorized personnel to attend the scene and document all names and actions of persons entering and exiting the scene
Document who entered the scene prior to your arrival and their activities
Is there evidence of medications or drugs? (places to look include: medicine cabinet, purses, refrigerator and waste baskets)

What may appear to be accidental or explainable death may be a homicide. The coroner/medical examiner is the only authority who may determine cause of death and may want to attend the scene. Advise supervisor and coroner of findings.
Symptoms of hypothermia can resemble death. Death can only be confirmed after the body has been warmed to normal temperature and resuscitation efforts have failed.
The death of a child caused by shaken baby syndrome is not readily detected during an external examination. The cause of such a death may be determined through pathological examination.

Most shaken baby cases result in retinal hemorrhages. Ensure an ophthalmologist is consulted. Other injuries consistent with shaken baby syndrome are grab sites (bruises around shoulders or chest) or fractures of skull, ribs, or legs. Neck injuries are rarely observed.

Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) is defined as natural death which sudden and unexpected but remains unexplained. Possible cause of death has been ruled out by an examination of the scene, a thorough investigation, an autopsy, and a medical review.
Consider support services such as General Investigation Section (GIS), Major Crimes Unit (MCU), Forensic Identification Section (FIS)
Enter scene by route least likely to disturb evidence, noting route of travel
Check victim for signs of life. (Breathing, neck area for pulse, etc.)
Note time of arrival
Living victim

additionalQuestions.output: Summons medical assistance
Dying Declarations

questions.output: Conscious victim: If victim is conscious, attempt to obtain the following information

additionalQuestions.output: Who did this to you?
If name of assailant not known to victim, commence identification by description: man, woman, race, height, weight, color of hair, eyes, type of clothing, etc.
Establish the fact that the victim knows that he/she is dying

questions.output: Unconscious Victim: If victim is unconscious on arrival at scene. Make sure that a police officer remains with victim at all times, including trip to hospital so that any dying declarations made during conscious periods can be noted
Upon arrival at hospital alert medical personnel of a possibility of dying declarations. Request them to note same if made during operative period
Request to be notified if victim regains consciousness so that you will be present when any dying declarations made
Before removal...

additionalQuestions.output: If possible, photograph victim's position at scene before removal.
If time and circumstance do not permit photos before victim removed carefully note the position of the victim in your report.
Obtain physical evidence from victim

questions.output: Officer accompanying victim to hospital should collect victim's clothing and personal effects as they become available.
Officer receiving items should carefully note time received and the identity of person from whom items were received.

If necessary for identification, items handled by physicians, nurses should be marked by those persons and the chain of custody noted. This is particularly important with items such as bullets, etc. Medical personnel should not attempt to identify caliber or types of firearms used.
NOTE: A failure to follow up on collecting items that left the crime scene with the victim may cause their loss or render them useless as evidence.
Notify command of your situation. Request Assistance i.e.: Major Crime Unit, General Investigation Section, Forensic Identification Unit etc.

Notify or request notification of Crown Counsel representative. Only for legal questions, do not allow a lawyer to get involved in the actual investigation. Their training limits them to the providing advice on legal issues only.
Notify or request notification of medical examiner.
Block or rope off scene (A Bigger is better)
Persons at scene

additionalQuestions.output: Clear unauthorized person from the scene. NOTE: You cannot worry about hurting someone’s feelings. If they do not belong tell them to leave. This must include any unauthorized police command.
Prevent anyone from touching the body or disturbing anything pending the arrival of the medical examiner, identification personnel, and investigative officers.

questions.output: Witnesses

additionalQuestions.output: Note name and address of persons present
Obtain brief statement from each person present
Hold witnesses until arrival of investigators.
Keep witnesses separate to prevent conversation
Prevent destruction of fragile evidence such footprints, tire, tracks, etc.

questions.output: Process Scene

additionalQuestions.output: CAUTION - Be aware that there are search and seizure problems in this area. If in doubt you may wish to contact your Crown Counsel regarding a warrant or other advice.

NOTE: At night, obtain adequate lighting before scene processing commences. Artificial lighting used must be adequate for photography and for minute detail search for items such as hair, cartridge cases, etc.
WHEN LIGHTING NOT AVAILABLE: Secure scene under guard and wait for daylight before processing is commenced.

questions.output: Note time of arrival
Note weather conditions, especially at outdoor crime scenes.
Check perimeter of scene to insure that all of scene is secured.
Obtain summary of situation from officer in charge.
Photograph scene. Take color photographs of the scene from all angles. Work from the perimeter to center (Include photographs of entrance, exit routes to scene.)
There is no such thing as too many photographs of a crime scene.
Make sure that all possible locations relevant to scene are photographed. Particularly important that all rooms a scene are photographed.
Something may have happened in an adjoining room that will be critical importance as the investigation develops.

Photograph specific items of evidence such as footprints, cartridge cases, weapons, etc. as observed in place at scene. Where scale is important (footprints, tire tracks, etc.) use ruler scale to show size.
Take overhead photographs

additionalQuestions.output: Should be taken of outdoor scenes, including streets, intersection. These can be invaluable in constructing scale representation of scene.
Drones, Extension ladders, power company and fire trucks should be utilized for this purpose.

questions.output: Video Tape

additionalQuestions.output: Video tape recordings should be made of scene where possible.
Include videotape shots of collecting evidence, examining victim at scene.
Also video tape defendant and witnesses.

questions.output: Photograph victim at scene

additionalQuestions.output: Color photographs should be taken of deceased from all angles.
Photograph deceased as items are removed from body: identification, clothing, etc.
Photograph substances on body and clothing of deceased such as blood, seminal fluid, powder residue, etc. These should include full length and close-ups.
Photograph wounds, injuries (include close-ups). This should be done step by step as body examined and disrobed by medical examiner at scene.

questions.output: Make careful note of following

additionalQuestions.output: Position of body
Position, condition of clothing
Location of substances on deceased and their clothing
Any alteration of deceased’s position before your arrival as determined from witnesses or officers.

questions.output: Survey scene

additionalQuestions.output: Take careful measurements of the scene. Measure each room in a house NOTE: it is very hard to return later to a scene if you do not have a warrant.
Use a reference point is permanent.

questions.output: Deceased

additionalQuestions.output: Before removing examine deceased for physical evidence Example: loose hairs, fibers, etc.
Place deceased on a cloth sheet, move body shortest possible distance
Examine the ground underneath the victim
Examine deceased for additional physical evidence that may become visible after movement.
Collect physical evidence from deceased to include personal effects, clothing, shoes, weapons, etc.

questions.output: Scene area

additionalQuestions.output: Organize scene search by adopting specific plan. Assign tasks, areas of search to individual officers.
Assign ONE officer to collect, mark and transport items found.
Execute search by carefully following plan of assigned tasks.

Note, mark and photograph location of objects found such as latent: Fingerprints, footprints, tire tracks, tool marks, hair, fragments of cloth, buttons, cigarette butts, cartridge cases, bullet holes, bullets, bloodstains, etc.
Collect, mark evidence. REMEMBER - When collecting evidence DO NOT overlook such items as room furniture, doors, etc. That can be used to reconstruct crime scene in court.

Preserve items of evidence individually. i. Do not place separate items of evidence in same container. (Example: mixing items of clothing in one bag can compromise evidence such as head or pubic hair when the location of such items on a particular garment is critical. ii. Use correct container - molded plastic container for blood. Paper bindle for hair or fiber. Paper bag for bloody items. Never put evidence that may decompose or deteriorate into a plastic bag. iii. Provide information to lab personnel concerning source of item, what test you desire performed. Make contact with the lab personnel and give a brief account of what your investigation shows.

questions.output: Photograph defendant

additionalQuestions.output: Show any injuries or lack of injuries
Show his clothing and general appearance
Show hands (Both sides)
Show any tattoos or scars

questions.output: Take any evidence that you are entitled to

additionalQuestions.output: Public combing if rape case
Any item that is on the clothing and could be lost
Obtain warrant for blood and hair samples

questions.output: Autopsy processing

additionalQuestions.output: Arrange through the medical examiner the transportation of the victim to morgue
Medical Examiner investigator or police officer should be present during the autopsy
If possible before autopsy take finger and palm prints of deceased. If not then once the autopsy is completed get the prints.
Pick up any evidence that was obtained during the autopsy, blood samples, hair samples, fingernail scrapings, bullets
NOTE: Place each item in a separate container. Paper bags are best. Each container should be marked, dated and initialed

questions.output: Investigative personnel

additionalQuestions.output: Obtain summary of situation from officer at scene.
Check scene security and take steps necessary to correct and errors or omissions, if any.
Review all actions of officers on the scene
Initiate Investigation from the beginning

Communicate information To your investigators to other agencies to PIO
Defendant

additionalQuestions.output: Advise of MIRANDA RIGHTS using card
Have defendant initial or sign rights card or get a verbal acknowledgment that defendant understands right

Video tape or record that defendant's statement i. Your choice if you tell defendant he/she is being recorded. ii. Turn tape from the start. iii. Questions should be designed to answer the unanswered questions that you have about the case. iv. If lawyer is present you must control the interview.

questions.output: Witnesses

additionalQuestions.output: Use your discretion as to video a witness or not i. Do tape if witness is reluctant ii. Not necessary if witness is cooperative iii. Unfortunately cost of tapes must be considered.

questions.output: Establish movements of deceased prior to death to determine:

Who with
Doing what
Location

Gang involvement

questions.output: Consider deceased's background
View scene information for evidence indicating motives such as:

additionalQuestions.output: Sex
Theft of money or property
Narcotics
Mental Derangement

questions.output: Determine actions of defendant before homicide

additionalQuestions.output: You may be required to cover period days, weeks or months before homicide depending on circumstances, including motive.
Pay attention to any unusual actions of defendant trips, absences from work, home, etc.
Cover any activities such as surveillance of victim purchase of weapons, etc.

questions.output: Determine actions of defendant after homicide

additionalQuestions.output: Fight
Destruction or concealment of: Clothing worn at crime scene Weapons used Vehicles used (including cleaning of same to remove bloodstains, etc.)

questions.output: Practical tips.

additionalQuestions.output: Call upon experienced investigators to assist.
Question thoroughly those concerned.
Be careful in questioning witnesses they may turn to be principals in the crime.
Do not divulge critical information carelessly to witnesses It may get back to the defense and you may end up with what you have told the witness instead of what he actually knows about the event.
Separate witnesses
Confer with your co-workers.
Cooperate with fellow officers
Be courteous and tactful.
Give constant attention to dissemination of pertinent information to other agencies.
Do not disclose valuable information to press or unauthorized persons.

questions.output: Facts of case must be reported. No investigation regardless of how competently executed is complete unless accurately reported.
REMEMBER - Reports are your channel of communication to command DA, fellow officers. Your case is never better than your report.
Contents of Report must include at least the following

additionalQuestions.output: Summary: A brief, concise summary of operative case facts at beginning of report. This puts case in narrative form, enables reader to grasp picture before examining balance of report for details, witnesses’ statements. Summary should not contain verbatim recital of witnesses statements.

List of Evidence: List items seized, using consecutive numbers for each individual item. Specify following: What, Were seized, From whom Where stored, Action taken - Specify if item given to lab personnel for testing, and, if so, to whom.
Action Needed: Specify any processing remaining to be done such as latent prints, lab testing, etc.
List of witnesses with brief statement of what testimony concerns; connection with case.
Witnesses Statements
Do not include: i. Your opinions concerning the value of case. ii. Irrelevant Material

Extended treatment?
Hospitalizations?
Other help seeking behavior?
Take note of the current time.
Collect as much driving evidence as possible.
Reason for vehicle stop. Speeding, too slow, crossing center line, crossing shoulder, swerving, erratic driving, driving complaint received, unregistered, etc.
Road and weather conditions.
Traffic conditions: A lot of vehicles on the road, pedestrians, etc.
How long did vehicle take to stop after emergency equipment activated?
How did the vehicle stop? Abruptly, too far on shoulder, too far onto highway, etc.
Query plate and advise communications center of location.
Note how many occupants in the vehicle.
Consider calling for assistance when outnumbered.
What are the occupants/driver doing upon approach. Changing seats, lighting cigarettes, etc.
Use senses as you approach: Smell of liquor/ drugs, sounds of occupants/bottles, etc.
Notice any open liquor or other physical evidence in back or front seat.
Observe driver's actions as you approach. Window already rolled down, smoking, nervous, etc.
Note damage to vehicle if any shown.
Driver observations: Red/pink eyes, slurred and labored speech, fumbling documents, confused, slow motor skills, tired looking, droopy eyelids, etc.
Does driver have horizontal gaze nostalgia.
Did driver provide you with the right documents drivers license, registration, insurance or gave you something unrelated.
Did the driver admit to drinking or to the use of drugs?
Isolate driver from passengers if officer is unsure if the smell of alcohol is from driver or from passengers.
If further investigation required proceed to arrest of driver section. If not release driver.
If reasonable grounds to believe driver is impaired exist, arrest/detain for breathalyzer testing.

If reasonable suspicion has been formed advise driver they are being detained for purpose of ASD test. Read driver ASD demand. (Driver detained for ASD not entitled to rights. If driver is detained 15 minutes or longer, they are entitled to their rights)
Wait 15 minutes from time of last drink to administer roadside screen device test. note results of breathalyzer test and show the driver. (10 minutes for cigarettes, 5 minutes for eating)

Test results: Test fail: Proceed to arrest for impaired operation of a motor vehicle, advise of rights and caution. Test Pass: Proceed with procedure for pass. Warning (Level at .05 or lower) Provide driver seven-day suspension, take license from driver, impound vehicle. Serve vehicle impound notice. (This is depending on prior convictions)
If driver does not provide proper samples, arrest on refusal of roadside.
If driver has the inability to provide a breathalyzer test, read blood demand.
Have driver exit vehicle and walk to the police vehicle.
How was driver when walking? (unsteady on feet, needed assistance, slow and labored)
Note what driver is wearing. (Loose clothes, tied or untied boots or shoes, jacket, anything that could be used as defense as to why they were walking the way they were)
Search and handcuff driver and place in back seat of police vehicle.
Can you detect smell of liquor/drugs on breath while in the back seat of police vehicle?
Read Charter, Breath Demand and Caution: Read Blood Demand if no sample provided. (due to inability of administering a breathalyzer test)
Make detailed notes of responses.
Search vehicle incidental to arrest seize any physical evidence: liquor bottles, drugs, etc.
Advise communications operator that you have one in custody and are returning to the office for breath tests.
Have breath tech attend office or Drug Recognition Expert if applicable.
Have vehicle towed by another police officer if possible. If not have it towed yourself. Make note of time.
While en-route, note the suspects demeanor and behavior: upset, placid, fell asleep, etc.
If suspect would like to speak to a lawyer, immediately bring into phone room upon arrival at detachment/station.
Note whether or not suspect needed help calling lawyer.
Note name of lawyer called and time call was received.
Note time call to lawyer ended.
Confirm suspect was satisfied with his call to his lawyer and if there is a need to call another.
Proceed to breathalyzer room.
Do not allow suspect to drink anything prior to tests being conducted.
Begin 15 minute observation period if required prior to testing.
Administer first breath test. Make note of how cooperative suspect was with providing breath sample.
Note if suspect followed all instructions given to them prior to testing.
If suspect did not provide sufficient breath samples make note of why. For example: claims of medical conditions, refused to provide samples, error on instrument, etc.
Seize and exhibit mouth piece if suitable sample not provided.
If subject is unwilling to provide samples, charge with failure to provide.
If the subject claims that they can not due to medical issues, call EMS to have checked over or bring to hospital to have doctor check subject out.

additionalQuestions.output: If doctor confirms medical issues, obtain blood samples.
If doctor confirms subject is able to provide breath samples. Give opportunity to provide samples again, if subject refuses again, charge accordingly.

questions.output: If initial test was successful, wait 20 minutes and administer second test.
Talk with subject while waiting. Making note of any evidence they may provide.
Fill out any relevant forms while waiting. Impaired Driving Checklists, etc.
Second test provided: if within 20mg%, conclude testing and charge if charges are available.
If difference in tests is above 20mg%, conduct a third test.
Again, if charges are available, charge accordingly.
Attempt to obtain Cautioned Statement from subject.
Fingerprint and photograph subject.
Query subject on CPIC and other computer applications to determine whether or not subject should be released or remanded.
Determine if subject should be released to a sober person or stay in custody due to high levels of intoxication. If levels are high enough, consider bringing subject to hospital to be checked out.
Complete and serve all required release documents.
If driver is found to have prior convictions, provide a 'Seek Greater Punishment Form'.
Verify and provide 'Certificate of Qualified Breath Test’ to accused. (Ensure that certificate is verified)
Serve with: Promise to Appear, Undertaking, Driving Prohibition, Driving Suspension, etc.
Have subject picked up or dropped off to responsible sober person.
Process all physical evidence into exhibit lockers: Seized liquor or drugs, etc.
Contact complainant if available and obtain a statement to capture driving evidence and/or evidence to support subject's intoxication level.
Attempt to obtain statements from any potential witnesses if brought to light during investigation: bartender, family members, waitresses, etc.
Attempt interview of the subject when sober.
If tests conducted outside 2-hour time frame, obtain services of breath test expert.
Document file in a timely fashion and according to policy.
Complete court disclosure forms if required.
Provide copies of officer(s) notes.
Certificate of Analysis.
Evidence tickets from breath instrument.
Release documents: Promise to Appear, Summons, Undertaking, etc.
Provincial documents: Notice of Driving Prohibition, Temporary Suspension, Vehicle Tow Form, etc.
Provide Photographs taken if any.
Photocopy of driver's license.
Occurrence reports.
Criminal record.
Provincial driving record.
Who's the caller? Name, DOB, Address, Phone #, etc.
Address of theft.
What was stolen? When?
Who's the victim: Name, DOB, Address, Phone #, etc.
Any suspects: Name, description.
Obtain victim statement.
Is there a witness? Obtain a witness statement.
What was stolen? make and model.
Is there a serial number?
Description of stolen item(s). colors, distinguishing marks, anything written on it? etc.
Does the victim have a picture of the stolen item?
Photograph where the item was stolen from.
If item was shoplifted, photograph identical items in store along with price tag.
Conduct an inventory of item(s) believed missing.
How much is the stolen item worth?
Does the victim have a receipt?
Does the victim have the box the stolen item came in?
Location of where the item was stolen?
Name and/or description of any suspects.
Why are they suspects?
Is there a surveillance or security video?
If somebody touched an item that is to be fingerprinted, get their information. Same applies to footprints.
Is there a need for Forensic Identification Unit to attend?

additionalQuestions.output: Do fingerprints need to be lifted from secured objects.
Shoe or foot impressions off of secured objects.
Severity of Theft: value, victims on scene during, had there been a rash of thefts lately, etc.
Need for more professional photographs.
Likelihood of fingerprints/footprints/shoe impressions being lifted? Dusty surfaces, smeared prints, gloves being used?
Tire impressions.
DNA left behind: Broken glass, cigarette butts, urine, feces, saliva, etc.

questions.output: If identifications services needed.

additionalQuestions.output: Keep scene secure.
Cover outside evidence until Forensic Identification Section attends.
Begin taking statements.

questions.output: If Forensic Identification Section not required to attend, continue with investigation.
Was it a crime of opportunity?
If anything can be added to CPIC, add it! (Ex. Item serial number)
Conduct neighbourhood inquiries.
Contact pawn shops with description of stolen items. If stolen item is there, seize item and obtain surveillance video and employee statement.
Media Release, Crime Stoppers, city website, and bulletin to other agencies.
Social Media sites.
Search Internet Classified ads sites: (kijiji.com, ebay.com, etc.) for stolen items.
Talk to or email other members of your police force to determine if they have any related files with any suspects.
If theft took place in a business, consider having staff complete a view questionnaire to try to pinpoint a suspect.
If suspect on scene or located later, arrest for theft or possession of stolen property, whichever applies.
Handcuff suspect.
Read Rights to Counsel Sec 10(b) C.C.C. make note of responses.
Read Police Caution, make note of responses.
If the accused was or could have been talking to another police officer read the Secondary Police Caution.
Search incident to arrest.
To ensure the safety of the police and the public.
To protect evidence.
To discover evidence.
Seize any evidence related to the offence.
If the item is re-sellable: Photograph the item and return to store.
If the item is not re-sellable: Seize exhibit and process same for court.
Bring suspect back to detachment/station.
Obtain Cautioned Statement.
Fingerprint and photograph.
If suspect is to be remanded: Bring to a Justice of the Peace for same.

If suspect is to be released: Serve Appearance Notice/Recognizance with or without sureties/or Promise to appear with an Undertaking providing conditions to stay away or have no contact with victim or business.
If charges are not going to be laid with an undertaking: Consider serving a trespass notice on the suspect.
If suspect is first time offender: Consider alternative measures program or recommend youth program. (i.e. If suspect is young offender).
Victim(s)

additionalQuestions.output: Full name, DOB, Address, Phone number, etc.
Determine timeline. When property was stolen, when last seen? When property was noticed missing?
What was stolen? make, model, description, current or original value ($), serial numbers.
Any prior issues with anyone/suspects in the past? Debts owed, other disputes, disgruntled employees, family disputes, disputes with clients? etc.
Any suspects? Description.
Why are they a suspect?
Determine relationship with the suspect.
Try to determine how the suspect stole the item.
Does the accused have any ownership to the stolen property?
Could the victim pick the suspect out of a photo lineup?
Why would anyone commit the theft?
Are they insured or are they making a claim through insurance.
Suspect Cautioned Statement should be included under statements.
Advise victim of Victim Impact Statement and Victim Services.
If item stolen is not sellable or damaged: Get the restitution form signed by victim.

questions.output: Witness

additionalQuestions.output: Full name, DOB, Address, Phone number, etc.
What did he/she witness?
Where was the item when it was taken?
Any suspects? If yes, why?
Did the witness see the suspect take the item?
Describe the suspect.
When was the item stolen?
What role does the witness have in the theft.
Does the witness know the suspect and how?
Do they know who owns the items stolen?
Does the witness know if the suspect(s) know who owns the item stolen?
Any previous history between the suspect and victim or witness?
Could the witness pick the suspect out of a photo lineup?

questions.output: Full Name, DOB, Address, Phone number, etc.
Did they take the item?
Did they move it with intent to steal it?
Why did they take it?
To convert it for their use or the user of another person
To deprive the owner or anyone other person of it
To use it for a deposit or security
To damage it or cause it inoperable
To deal with it in such a manner that it cannot be restored in the condition it was when taken
Who owned it?
When did they take it?
How did they take it?
If the suspect denies taking the item, consider interrogating the suspect.
Consider the use of a polygraph examiner.
Secure scene: ensure public is safe.
Immediately check for tire impressions as fire department and other outside agencies could destroy any possible evidence.
Have power shut off to building if possible. Contact electric company.
If other Home/Building are nearby. Clear those Home/Building in case flames jump structures.
Take photos upon arrival.
Determine if anyone is inside the Home/Building.

Walk the perimeter of the Home/Building to look for any signs of evidence. Gas cans left behind, matches, lighters, broken glass from Molotov cocktails, footprints, other off highway vehicle tracks, etc.
Determine property representative. Homeowner, renter, house sitter etc.
Is it possible to determine the cause or location fire was set.
Determine if there are any explosives in the Home/Building.
Determine if there was electricity on in the Home/Building.
Has the owner/property rep had electrical issues in the past?
Determine what type of heating source is being used. Electrical, oil, propane, wood, etc.
Determine if anyone smokes in the Home/Building.
Is there insurance on the Home/Building.
Call the Forensic Identification unit to attend. Have them obtain photo's and seize any physical evidence.
If Forensic identification section is not going to attend. Obtain photos and seize any physical evidence you come across.
Determine if Specialized Unit should be utilized. Major Crime Unit, General investigation Unit, Arson unit, etc.
Liaise with the Fire Marshal to determine if fire suspicious.
A trained arson investigator should assist the Fire Marshal with the scene examination.
Take detailed notes of scene.
Obtain a statement from the Home/Building owner/property rep and anyone else that might live in the residence.
Determine if there are any other flammable items in the Home/Building. Gas cans, lawn mowers, gas generators, etc.
Determine what variables nearby that may have started the fire.
Determine if this was a hate motivated crime.
Determine if the owner/property rep has anyone in mind that might have the motive to set the fire.
Obtain Fire Report form the Fire Marshall's office.
Investigations under this Act are carried out on behalf of the Provincial Fire Marshall.
At the request of the local fire chief investigate fires occurring in your area to ascertain if there is evidence of fraud, arson, loss of life or other suspicious circumstances.
If you suspect a criminal offence, investigate in the normal manner.
The following fire will be reported to Criminal Operations:
Residential/business $300,000 or more.
Nursing homes/schools and all Government property.
Conduct neighborhood inquiries.
Is there video available nearby that may have caught the fire starting.
Death/serious injury involved.
Suspected arsons, where damage exceeds $20,000.
Name of victim?
Where is the victim?
Offer medical and psychological services.
When did the sexual assault take place?
Where did sexual assault take place?
Are there any witnesses? Who will be on scene when police arrive?
Are there any suspects? Describe height, weight, build, hair color, hair length, glasses, eyes, speech (deep or high voice, soft, impediments), clothing worn, scars, marks, tattoos, etc.
Is there any weapons involved?
How did the sexual assault take place? (rape, touching, etc.)
Arrange medical assistance immediately.
Question victim when the offence took place.
Question victim where did the offence took place.
Who is the offender?
Does the victim know the offender? If so, how? (In a relationship with, friend, casual acquaintance, coworker, etc.)
If offence took place recently, have other officers be on the lookout for suspect.
Send message to boardering police agencies to BOLO suspect and or vehicle.
Bring victim to the hospital ASAP to be examined by a doctor. Have an officer stay with victim at all times.
Use Sexual Assault Examination Kit if possible.

Carefully inventory his/her personal belongings to ensure nothing is missing, specifically photographs, identification, jewelry and underwear. (As these are typical souvenirs or trophies collected by some offenders). The offender might have kept a belonging.
Consider collecting biological material containing DNA at any crime scene where designated offence has occurred.
Bodily substances most often sampled are blood, hair, saliva, etc.

Seize items which have the highest probability of containing bodily substances e.g. cigarette butts, gum, eating utensils, drinking glasses, personal grooming items, tissues, clothing, upholstery, bedding. Exercise the the utmost care when handling crime scene exhibits that will be submitted for forensic DNA analysis.
Wear proper protective equipment e.g. disposable gloves and mask to prevent contamination of the exhibits.
Collect, handle, and package exhibits separately.
Contact Forensic Identification Unit.
Have supervisor contact Major crimes Unit, GIS, Sexual Assault Unit, Police Dog Unit and/or any other unit that possibly could help or take over the investigation.
Attend crime scene with victim if at all possible.
Have victim describe everything that happend at the scene including how and where the assault(s) took place.
Seize any evidence of the offence and/or anything that can corroborate anything the victim/witness disclosed.
Photos of crime scene, include exactly where the assault(s) took place.
Photograph the crime scene.
Conduct neighborhood inquiries.
Check property and surrounding properties for video surveillance that may have captured anything related to offence.
ITO and Warrant for any vehicles or anything needed to be seized and examined from the crime scene.
Photo line up.
Complete ViCLAS.
If ID of suspect is issued, contact the National Sex Offender Registry and request a query of their database for a list of known sex offenders in the region.
DNA Warrant.
Obtain services of mental health professional.
Victim Services.
Pre charge approval for Sexual Offences Witnesses?
If offender is unknown, contact your Provincial/Territorial Registry Center to request a query of the NSOR database for a list of the known sex offenders in the area/region.
Victim Statement

additionalQuestions.output: Obtain a statement from the victim.
Describe the offender.
Does the victim know the offender?
How does the victim know the offender? Are they related, friends, coworkers, casual acquaintance, etc.
How did the offender initially approach and gain control over the victim?
How did the offender maintain control over the victim and the situation throughout the assault (threatening gestures, verbal threats, threatening third parties, escape prevention, etc.)
Describe the physical force that was used and when during the attack it was used. (Subtle forms of force and threat of physical force)
Describe every instance of resistance whether it be passive, verbal or physical. (Passive resistance is non compliant, e.g. not doing what the offender demands, not saying anything and not fighting)
Describe the offenders reaction immediately following each time the victim resisted.
Describe any sexual dysfunctions the offender experienced (e.g. inability to obtain or maintain an erection, premature or retarded ejaculation)

If the offender was dysfunctional, try to determine if he/she was able to overcome the dysfunction, as well as any behavior or act he/she performed or demanded he/she preform as a means of overcoming the dysfunction
Describe the sexual acts the offender forced upon him/her, as well as each act performed on himself/herself, in the sequence in which it occurred, including repetitions.
Repeat everything that the offender said to him/her, using the offender's words rather than the victim's paraphrasing of what was said.
Ask him/her to describe the offender's tone of voice and apparent attitude at the time he/she made the statement.
Describe any questions he/she was asked by the offender, any phrases or verbal statement he/she demanded he/she repeat, again using the offender's words rather than the victim's paraphrases.

Describe any changes in the offender's attitude. If there was a change try to determine what his/her attitude changed to and what happened or stopped happening immediately prior to each change in attitude.
Describe any actions the offender took to ensure that he/she would not be able to identify him/her or any precautions he/she took to ensure police would not be able to associate him/her to the crime.

Recall if he/she has had any experiences which might indicate that the offender specifically targeted him/her. He/she may have received calls, notes or other forms of contact from a stranger prior to or following the offence.
Describe the offender in terms of how he/she thinks the offender would be viewed by their people.

questions.output: Who's the caller?
Name, DOB, Address, Phone #.
Address of Assault?
Who's the victim? (Name, DOB, Address, Ph#)
How was the victim assaulted? (physical force, weapon)
Does the victim have any injuries?
Is Emergency Medical Services required?
What is the emotional status of all parties involved?
Is there any background noises? (threats, screams, dishes breaking, etc.)
Who's the suspect?
Are there any witnesses?
Relation of the victim and suspect?
Query all involved on CPIC and any other police information program available.
History of weapons/assaults with anyone involved?
Prior to going into the scene, stop, listen and pay attention to your other senses.
Does anyone require immediate medical assistance?
Secure scene.
If possible, separate all parties involved.
Determine who was involved and what role they had, i.e.: victim, suspect, witnesses.
Do children reside in the home or were there children present during altercation?
Did the children witness anything? if so, interview.
Obtain initial version of what took place.
Determine type of assault that took place. (Common assault, assault with a weapon, assault causing bodily harm, domestic assault, aggravated assault)
If reasonable grounds exist, arrest suspect, search and secure in police vehicle.
Read Charter of Rights and Police Caution to the suspect.
Obtain photographs of scene, victim and injuries, weapons, injuries to suspect which may corroborate stories, etc.
Seize any weapons or physical evidence that could be used to corroborate offence.
Obtain all information of all involved.
Is alcohol/drugs a factor?
Determine if the suspect fled scene and with whom.
If suspect fled scene, determine if there is any physical evidence available to determine identification, fingerprints, foot/shoe impressions, statements form witnesses/victim.

Take time to make detailed notes of scene, what the victim(s) and witnesses say prior to statements obtained, and any utterances from the suspect prior to arrest or cautioned statement being obtained.
Determine if Forensic Identification Unit is needed to attend.
If so, keep scene secured until arrival.
If not, continue with investigation.
Determine if any other support units might be needed. (Major crime units, police dog unit, general investigation unit, etc.)
If victim is injured and has to attend hospital for medical examination, attend with the victim and note injuries.
Note if doctor states if injuries are consistent with the assault.
Determine if the injuries are merely transient or trifling in nature or if the suspect wounds, maims, disfigures or endangers the life of the victim.
If able, have the victim sign consent to release medical information at the hospital.
If the victim is unable to understand what he is signing, wait until victim is able to understand and have him sign at a later time.
Determine if this could have been avoided in any way, by the victim suspect or witnesses present.
Determine what environmental factors could have played a part in the outcome.
Determine if the suspect has the ability, means and intent to commit the assault.
Is there a history of violence with the parties involved?
Consider an Emergency Protection Order.
Obtain statements from everyone involved.
Neighborhood inquiries.
Is there any video from residence, business or neighboring businesses available?
Process any exhibits seized for the investigation.
Have weapons fingerprinted and analyzed for DNA.
Notify any support units. (i.e. Child and family services, Victim services, etc.)
Determine your forces policy on these types of offences.
Domestic assault policy could require a charge to be sworn if evidence exists of an assault even if victim does not provide statement or want to pursue charges.
Is there any provincial/municipal/federal statues you should take into consideration? (i.e.: Victims of Family Violence Act)
If suspect on scene or located later, Arrest for theft under/over $5000. (Sec 10(a)C.C.C)
Handcuff suspect.
Read rights to Counsel Sec 10 (b) C.C.C make note of responses.
Read Police Caution, make note of responses.
If the accused was or could have been talking to another police read the Secondary Police Caution.
Search incident to arrest  (1) to ensure the safety of the police and the public;  (2) to protect evidence;  (3) to discover evidence.
Seize any evidence related to the offence.
Process at the detachment.
Attempt to obtain a cautioned statement.
Fingerprint and photograph.
If suspect is to be remanded, bring to a Justice of the Peace or a judge as soon as possible.

If suspect is to be released serve Appearance Notice/Recognizance with or without sureties/ or Promise to Appear with an Undertaking providing conditions to stay away or have no contact with victim, victims address or business, and any other conditions to ensure the safety of the victim(s) or witnesses.
If charges are not going to be laid with conditions, consider serving a trespass notice on the suspect.
Victim

additionalQuestions.output: Determine whether or not KGB statement should be taken.
Full name, DOB, Address, Ph#.
Have victim provide pure version statement.
Follow up with non leading questions.
Does the victim know who the suspect is/was?
Determine history of the relationship between the victim and suspect.
Determine how the victim was assaulted.
Determine timeline of assault.
If assaulted with a weapon, have the victim explain what the weapon was, where it came from, how the suspect used it against the victim, where it went after the assault.
If injuries were sustained, have victim describe injuries.
If medical assistance was rendered, have victim explain what the paramedic/doctor said they were.
If the suspect can not be identified, could the victim identify the suspect from a photo lineup?
Why would the suspect commit the assault? (Intent)
Have the victim determine the means of the assault? (weapon, physical force, etc.)
Have the victim determine the ability of the suspect. (suspect has martial arts training, suspect size and/or physical abilities, etc.)
Could the victim have avoided the assault?
What actions did the victim take during the assault? (fight back, defending self, consensual fight, etc.)
Will the victim sign a consent to release medical records?
What was said prior to, during and after the assault took place?
Were there any witnesses present?
Does the victim fear that the suspect will commit any more offences towards the victim?
How did the assault affect the victim?
Does the victim want to provide a victim impact statement?
Does the victim want a referral to any available services that can be offered? (victim services, child and family services, etc.)
What are the victim's wishes with regards to how the investigation should proceed?
Consider re-interviewing victim after suspect alleges a different story.
Ask victim if address should remain confidential.

questions.output: Suspect Cautioned Statement

additionalQuestions.output: Obtain video or audio recorded statement.
Read Cautioned Statement Form.
Have suspect provided a Pure Version Statement.
Follow up with non leading questions.
Does the suspect know who the victim is/was?
Determine history of the relationship between victim and suspect.
Determine how the suspect assaulted the victim.
Determine timeline of assault.
If assaulted with a weapon, have the suspect explain what the weapon was, where it came from, how the suspect used it against the victim, where it went after the assault.
If injuries were sustained, have suspect describe the injuries.
Why would the suspect commit the assault? (Intent)
Have the suspect explain the means of the assault. (Weapon, physical force, etc.)
Have the suspect determine his/her abilities. (suspect has martial arts training, suspects size and/or physical abilities, etc.)
Could the suspect have avoided the assault?
What actions did the victim take during the assault? (fight back, defending self, consensual fight, etc.)
What was said prior to, during and after the assault took place?
Were there any witnesses present?
Does the suspect show any remorse for his/her actions?
Does the suspect take responsibilities for his/her actions?
What would happen if the suspect was released? Would he re-offend?
If the suspect denies his part, consider interrogating the suspect.
Is the suspect willing to take a polygraph test?

Have witness provide Pure Version Statement.
Follow up with indirect questioning.
Does the witness know who the suspect/victim is/was?
Determine history of the relationship between the victim and suspect, and between the witness and the two involved parties.
Determine how the victim was assaulted.
Determine timeline of assault.
If assaulted with a weapon, have witness explain what the weapon was, where if came from, how the suspect used it against the victim, where if went after the assault.
If the suspect can not be identified, could the witness identify the suspect from a photo lineup?
Why would the suspect commit the assault? (Intent)
Have the witness determine the means of the assault. (weapon, physical force, etc..)
Have the witness determine the ability of the suspect. (suspect has martial arts training, suspects size and/or physical abilities, etc.)
Could the victim have avoided the assault?
What actions did the victim take during the assault. (fighting back, defending self, consensual fight, etc.)
What was said prior to, during and after assault took place?
Were there any other witnesses present?
How did the assault affect the witness?
